case_name: Badri Narain Singh v. Kam Deo Prasad

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 563 of 1960 was filed as an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 20, 1959, of the Patna High Court in Election Appeal No. 8 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 563 of 1960. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated March 20, 1959, of the Patna High Court in Election appeal No. 8 of 1958.

facts.text: Badri Narain Singh, the appellant, and four other persons including Kam Deo Prasad (respondent No. 1) and respondent No. 2 were candidates to the Bihar Legislative Assembly during the general election held in 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Badri Narain Singh, the appellant, and four other persons including Kam Deo Prasad, respondents, were candidates to the Bihar Legislative Assembly during the last general election held in 1957.

facts.text: Two of the candidates withdrew before the relevant date.

anchor.surface_text: Two of those candidates withdrew before the relevant date.

facts.text: The appellant secured the largest number of votes and was declared elected on March 14, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant secured the largest number of votes and was declared elected on March 14, 1957.

facts.text: Respondent No. 2 secured a larger number of votes than Kam Deo Prasad, respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2 secured larger number of votes than Kam Deo Prasad, respondent No. 1, who filed an election petition

facts.text: Kam Deo Prasad filed an election petition under sections 80 and 81 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 challenging the election of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Respondent No. 2 secured larger number of votes than Kam Deo Prasad, respondent No. 1, who filed an election petition under ss. 80 and 81 of the Representation of the People Act, 1951  Act XLIII of 1951  challenging the election of the appellant,

facts.text: The election petition claimed that the nomination of the appellant and respondent No. 2, as Ghatwals holding an office of profit, was against section 7 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: challenging the election of the appellant, on the ground that the numberination of the appellant and respondent No. 2, who, as Ghatwals, held an office of profit, was against the provisions of s. 7 of the Act,

facts.text: The election petition alleged that the appellant committed corrupt practices.

anchor.surface_text: and that the appellant had also companymitted companyrupt practices.

facts.text: Kam Deo Prasad prayed for declaration that the election of the appellant was void and that he himself was duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: Kam Deo Prasad, by his election peti- tion, number only prayed for the declaration that the ,election of the appellant was void, but also for the declaration that he himself was duly elected.

facts.text: The appellant denied the allegations against him.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant denied the allegations against him.

facts.text: The Election Tribunal held that the appellant was guilty of corrupt practices.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal held that Badri Narain Singh, the appellant, was guilty of companyrupt practices and that a Ghatwal was number a holder of an office of profit under the State of Bihar.

facts.text: The Election Tribunal held that a Ghatwal was not a holder of an office of profit under the State of Bihar.

anchor.surface_text: The Election Tribunal held that Badri Narain Singh, the appellant, was guilty of companyrupt practices and that a Ghatwal was number a holder of an office of profit under the State of Bihar.

facts.text: The Election Tribunal set aside the election of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It therefore set aside the election of the appellant, but did number grant the dec- laration that Kam Deo Prasad was a duly elected candidate.

facts.text: The Election Tribunal did not grant declaration that Kam Deo Prasad was duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: It therefore set aside the election of the appellant, but did number grant the dec- laration that Kam Deo Prasad was a duly elected candidate.

facts.text: Appellant filed Election Appeal No. 7 of 1958 in Patna High Court against the order setting aside his election.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant filed Election Appeal No. 7 of 1958 in the High Court of Judicature at Patna, against the order of the Election Tribunal setting aside his election,

facts.text: Kam Deo Prasad filed Election Appeal No. 8 of 1958 against the order not declaring him duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: Kam Deo Prasad also filed Election Appeal No. 8 against the order of the Election Tribunal number declaring him to be the duly elected candidate

facts.text: Patna High Court did not accept the finding that Badri Narain Singh committed corrupt practices.

anchor.surface_text: It did number accept the finding of the Election Tribunal that Badri Narain Singh had companymitted any companyrupt practice

facts.text: Patna High Court accepted that Badri Narain Singh and respondent No. 2 held offices of profit as Ghatwals under Bihar Government.

anchor.surface_text: and accepted the companytention for respondent No. 1 that Badri Narain Singh and respondent No. 2 held offices of profit under the Bihar Government as they were Ghatwals.

facts.text: Patna High Court confirmed setting aside of appellant's election and declared Kam Deo Prasad duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: It was in this view of the matter that it companyfirmed the order of the Election Tribunal setting aside the election of the appellant and allowing the appeal of respondent No 1, declared him duly elected.

facts.text: High Court dismissed Election Appeal No. 7 of 1958 and allowed Election Appeal No. 8 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, Election Appeal No. 7 of 1958 is dismissed, and Election Appeal No. 8 of 1958 is allowed, and Kam Deo Prasad Singh is declared to be duly elected

facts.text: Kam Deo Prasad Singh declared duly elected to Bihar Legislative Assembly from Sarnath State Assembly Constituency in Santal Parganas district.

anchor.surface_text: Kam Deo Prasad Singh is declared to be duly elected to Bihar Legis- lative Assembly from the Sarnath State Assembly Constituency in the district of Santal Parganas.

facts.text: Separate decrees were prepared in Election Appeal No. 7 and No. 8.

anchor.surface_text: As a result of this order, separate decrees were As a result of this order, separate decrees were As a result of this order, separate decrees were prepared in the two appeals.

facts.text: Appellant filed this appeal by special leave against the order in Election Appeal No. 8 of 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant has filed this appeal by special leave against the order in Election Appeal No. 8 of 1958.

facts.text: Preliminary objection raised by respondent Kam Deo Prasad Singh that appeal is barred by res judicata because appellant did not appeal against Election Appeal No. 7.

anchor.surface_text: A preliminary objection has been taken on behalf of respondent Kam Deo Prasad Singh that this appeal is incompetent as barred by the principle of res judicata inasmuch as the appellant did number appeal against the order of the High Court in Appeal No. 7

facts.text: Court held that judgment in Election Appeal No. 7 does not operate as res judicata in this appeal.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that both in view of the facts of the case and the provision of law applicable to that case, that case can be numberguide for determining the question before us in this appeal.

facts.text: The two appeals before High Court had different subject matters.

anchor.surface_text: The subject matter of each appeal was, however, different. The subject matter of appeal No. 7 filed by the appellant related to the question of his election being bad or good

facts.text: High Court came to two separate decisions in the two appeals.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the High Court in the two appeals, though stated in one judgment, really amounted to two decisions and number to one decision companymon to both the appeals.

facts.text: Appellant cannot question the finding that he held an office of profit in this appeal as order in Appeal No. 7 stands.

precedents.cited_proposition: judgment in one appeal does not operate as res judicata in another appeal arising from the same proceeding where there are separate decrees and distinct subject matters
precedents.cited_holding: where there has been one trial, one finding, and one decision, there need not be two appeals even though two decrees may have been drawn up... The question of res judicata arises only when there are two suits
